results.title: Beef Carcase Competition
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this film contains footage of dead animals.

This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was made to promote and highlight the pristine quality beef produced in the Western district of Victoria and Eastern South Australia.

It documents the annual contest to select the best beef carcase; in this instance, held in Portland, Victoria.

results.title: Vine grafting
results.brief_description: Deals with several methods of cutting and grafting for production of Phylloxera resistant grapevine canes in the north of Victoria. The film shows the activities of the staff of the Rutherglen research station inside the sheds and in the field, planting and propagating the canes.

results.title: Peach and pear harvester
results.brief_description: Picture only. Footage of specialised machine used for quickly removing fruit from peach and pair trees. The machine envelopes a tree and then vibrates which causes the fruit to fall off into a catching device. This is an odd process to view as the tree is shaken quite violently by the machine and the fruit falls into the catching device in a dramamtic fashion.

results.title: Packing apples for export
results.brief_description:
Film explains how to correctly pack and store apples for export to Enlgand on ships. Features footage of early automated fruit processing technology, as well as women sorting through apples and packing them. Nice shots, also, of people picking apples and placing them in steel buckets. Classic apple-picking imagery with rich reds and greens. Some slow-motion footage of ‘expert’ demonstrating how to wrap an apple before packing. End of film shot at docks with numerous crates being hiosted onto ships. Narration is upbeat and light.

Beautiful illustrated title and end credits featuring text-over-apples.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 2)
results.brief_description:
General shots (rushes) of Melbourne ‘life’ from the 50s. All images very iconic and nostalgic.

Section 1. Football match between Carlton and Richmond at Punt Road oval. Huge crowd. Good shots of football being played and the crowd reacting to the game.

Section 2. Two women at an observation point above the city.

Section 3. Shot of State Library with tram going past, shot of two statues in the city.

Section 4. Shots taken from behind St Paul’s cathederal looking down towards the Yarra, MCG and Flinders St train tracks.

Section 5. Shots of various statues and fountains around Melbourne.

Section 6. Shot from car driving along St Kilda Road, away from the city.

Section 7. Shots of city in the afternoon. Busy scene with Cars, buses, trams and people.

Section 8. Shot looking towards city from bank of Yarra. A man sits on a park bench in the foreground, surrounded by Seagulls.

results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Bob Harper
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.

results.title: Marmalade
results.brief_description:
Takes viewer through the process of cutting citrus fruit, cooking it and bottling it as marmalade. A woman prepares the marmalade and a male voice narrates the process.

Good titles/ ‘The End’. Nice colour.

results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: A Crop of records
results.brief_description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.
